awd_titl_txt: The Role of Executive Function in Mathematics and Science Learning Difficulties of Students with Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Executive function (EF) deficits may explain lower math and science achievement for students with and without disabilities and therefore may be essential targets for intervention.  Current research in this area often relies on cross-sectional studies using smaller samples of middle and high school students and so this study fills a critical gap by examining relationships between executive function and math and science achievement with younger students in a large, nationally representative longitudinal data set.  The study will also explore how performance in these subjects could be negatively impacting students' self-efficacy and views toward math and science. The project's findings will inform screening, monitoring, and intervention efforts for students with or at risk for disabilities when these efforts may be most effective.

This project will use the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten Cohort (ECLS-K) data set to investigate whether executive function deficits are related to lower mathematics and science achievement for at-risk students and students with disabilities.  The researchers will use growth mixture modeling to identify early trajectories of EF and science and math achievement.  The ECLS-K dataset is a large, nationally representative cohort of students followed from Kindergarten until the end of fifth grade.  While controlling for a number of confounding variables, the researchers will use multivariate regression models to identify potential areas of STEM intervention.  

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
We analyzed the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study, Kindergarten Class of 2010-2011 (ECLS-K: 2011) data to examine to what extent children’s executive functions are related to their academic achievement in mathematics, science, and reading as well as classroom behavior. We also examined to what extent deficits in executive functions specifically increased children's risk for academic difficulties by the primary grades and across elementary school. Additional work has examined to what extent executive functions may act as mediators for achievement gaps. Collectively, this work is providing additional empirical evidence of the extent to which executive functions may serve as modifiable factors for increasing mathematics, science, and reading achievement during the elementary grades. 

We observed that executive functions by kindergarten were consistently related to both children's academic achievement and classroom behavior. For example, a standard deviation (SD) increase in kindergarten children's working memories predicted .06 and .10 of a SD increase in their 2nd grade mathematics and science achievement, respectively, in analyses adjusted for many potential confounds (e.g., prior mathematics or science achievement, family SES, other types of executive functions). The odds that children displaying deficits in working memory in kindergarten later displayed mathematics difficulties in 1st grade were about three times larger than observationally similar kindergarten children who were not displaying deficits in working memory. Kindergarten children displaying deficits in executive functions, particularly in working memory, were more likely in adjusted analyses to display persistent difficulties in mathematics, science, and reading across elementary school. Analyses controlling for prior achievement also indicated that working memory mediated the associations between family SES and racial background and academic achievement. 

Collectively, our analyses help clarify that executive functions are independently predictive of children's academic achievement including in mathematics, science, and reading as well as their classroom behavior. This is the case both generally and specifically in the case for deficits in executive functions. Children displaying deficits in executive functions are at increased risk for experiencing academic difficulties. These relations are not explained by many measured confounds including the strong confounds of prior academic achievement or behavior. 

Across these analyses, children's working memory and inhibitory control may constitute especially promising targets of early interventions to increase mathematics, science, and reading achievement including for children who are at risk due to an early history of academic difficulties. Evidence-based screening and prevention efforts to address the early onset of academic difficulties in mathematics, science, and reading should help children experience greater educational and societal opportunity. We have reported this findings in high-impact and peer-reviewed journals including Child Development, Early Childhood Research Quarterly, and Contemporary Educational Psychology. We have presented the project’s findings at annual meetings of the American Educational Research Association. The project also supported the research training of a postdoctoral scholar and three doctoral students.
